citeinfo.title: Estimated Annual Recharge to the Edwards Aquifer in the San Antonio Area, by Stream Basin or Ungaged Area, 1934–2020

descript.abstract:
The Edwards aquifer in south-central Texas is one of the most permeable and productive aquifers in the United States and is the major source of public water supply for Bexar, Comal, Hays, Medina, and Uvalde Counties. The Edwards aquifer also supplies large quantities of water to agriculture, business, and industry in the region. The major artesian springs of the Edwards aquifer provide water for recreational activities, businesses, and downstream users, and provide habitat for several threatened or endangered species.
The areas pertinent to the recharge process are the catchment area and the recharge zone. The catchment area consists of the parts of river basins upstream from the recharge zone. Streams in the catchment area generally gain water (hence the term "catchment area") as they flow toward the recharge zone. As the streams flow across the recharge zone, which is essentially the outcrop of the Edwards aquifer, they lose substantial amounts of water through infiltration into the highly permeable, faulted and fractured rocks of the outcrop. Direct infiltration of rainfall also occurs in the interstream areas of the recharge zone.
Annual recharge estimates are based on data collected from a network of U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) streamflow-gaging stations at sites upstream and downstream from the recharge zone and on assumptions related to applying runoff characteristics from gaged areas to ungaged areas (Puente, 1978). Runoff is affected by the distribution of rainfall, which historically has been estimated from a network of rain gages, some operated by the USGS, some by the Edwards Aquifer Authority (EAA), and some by the National Weather Service. Since 2004, the distribution of rainfall has been estimated from calibrated NEXRAD (NEXt-generation weather RADar) data provided by the EAA. The annual estimation of recharge to the Edwards aquifer is part of a continuing program of the USGS in cooperation with the Edwards Aquifer Authority.
This data release is formatted as a tab-delimited file (.txt) that contains the estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer for 1934 through 2020. The estimated annual recharge is divided into eight major river basins of the catchment area and for some of those basins, will also include estimates of recharge from adjacent ungaged areas.
descript.purpose: Data are used by water resource managers for water resource planning and management.

place.placekey: 08190500 W Nueces River near Brackettville, Tex.
08196000 Dry Frio River near Reagan Wells, Tex.
08197500 Frio River below Dry Frio River near Uvalde, Tex.
08201500 Seco Creek at Miller Rh near Utopia, Tex.
08202700 Seco Creek at Rowe Rh near D'Hanis, Tex.
08179500 Medina Lake near San Antonio, Tex.
08178700 Salado Creek at Loop 410, San Antonio, Tex.
08168500 Guadalupe River above Comal River at New Braunfels, Tex.

srcinfo.srccontr: Provides streamflow data used to estimate recharge as described by Puente, 1978.
Provides rainfall record that is applied in the calculation of Edwards aquifer recharge estimates as described by Puente, 1978.

citeinfo.title: Method of estimating natural recharge to the Edwards Aquifer in the San Antonio area, Texas

procstep.procdesc: Annual recharge estimates are calculated using methods described by Puente, 1978. The annual recharge estimates are based on data collected from a network of U.S. Geological Survey streamflow-gaging stations at sites upstream and downstream from the recharge zone and on assumptions related to applying runoff characteristics from gaged areas to ungaged areas (Puente, 1978).

The recharge estimates can be affected by the distribution of rainfall, which historically has been estimated from a network of rain gages, some operated by the U.S. Geological Survey, some by the Edwards Aquifer Authority, and some by the National Weather Service. Since 2004, the distribution of rainfall has been estimated from calibrated NEXRAD (NEXt-generation weather RADar) data provided by the Edwards Aquifer Authority and is utilized in the calculation of recharge as described by Puente, 1978.

enttyp.enttypd: The .txt file contains estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer by eight defined river basins for 1934 through 2020.

attr.attrdef: The calendar year for which the recharge to the Edwards Aquifer was estimated.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Nueces and West Nueces River Basins.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Frio and Dry Frio River Basins which includes adjacent ungaged areas.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Sabinal River Basin which includes adjacent ungaged areas.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from Seco and Hondo Creek Basins which includes adjacent ungaged areas.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Medina River Basin which consists entirely of losses from Medina and Diversion Lake.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the area between the Medina River and Cibolo Creek Basins.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Cibolo and Dry Comal Creek Basins.
Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer from the Blanco River Basin which includes adjacent ungaged areas.
Total estimated annual recharge to the Edwards Aquifer.

enttyp.enttypd: The .txt file provides a summary of the basins; drainage areas included within the basins; and streamflow gages used to estimate recharge within the basins, along with the location of the streamflow gages.

edom.edomvd: Drainage area includes the Nueces and West Nueces River.
Drainage area includes the Frio and Dry Frio Rivers and the adjacent ungaged areas of the Leona River and Blanco Creek.
Drainage area includes the Sabinal River and the adjacent ungaged areas of Little Blanco, Nolton, and Ranchero Creeks.
Drainage area includes Seco and Hondo Creeks and the adjacent ungaged areas of Parkers, Live Oak, Verde, and Quihi Creeks.
Recharge to Edwards aquifer from Medina River consists entirely of losses from Medina and Diversion Lake System.
Drainage area includes San Geronimo, Leon, and Salado Creeks, and other smaller tributaries.
Drainage area of Cibolo Creek and Dry Comal Creek.
Drainage area includes the Blanco River and the adjacent ungaged drainage areas of Sink, Purgatory, York, and Alligator Creeks.

attr.attrdef: Drainage areas represented within the basin and contribute recharge to the Edwards aquifer.

edom.edomvd: Drainage area includes the Nueces and West Nueces Rivers.
Drainage area includes the Frio and Dry Frio Rivers and the adjacent ungaged drainage areas of the Leona River and Blanco Creek.
Drainage area includes the Sabinal River and the adjacent ungaged drainage areas of Little Blanco, Nolton, and Ranchero Creeks.

edom.edomv: Area between the Sabinal River and Medina River Basin
edom.edomvd: Drainage area includes Seco and Hondo Creeks and the adjacent ungaged drainage areas of Parkers, Live Oak, Verde, and Quihi Creeks.
Recharge to Edwards aquifer from Medina River Basin consists entirely of losses from Medina and Diversion Lake System.

edom.edomv: Area between the Medina River Basin and Cibolo-Dry Comal Creek Basin
edom.edomvd: Drainage area includes San Geronimo, Leon, and Salado Creeks, and other smaller tributaries.

edom.edomv: Cibolo Creek and Dry Comal Creek Basin
edom.edomvd: Drainage area includes the Cibolo and Dry Comal Creeks.
Drainage area includes the Blanco River and the adjacent ungaged drainage areas of Sink, Purgatory, York, and Alligator Creeks.

overview.eaover:
The catchment area which provides recharge to the Edwards aquifer is comprised of nine major drainage areas. These areas include the Nueces and West Nueces River basins (Basin 1); the Frio and Dry Frio River basins, which also includes the adjacent drainage areas of the Leona River and Blanco Creek (Basin 2); the Sabinal River basin (Basin 3), which also includes the adjacent areas of Little Blanco, Nolton, and Ranchero Creeks; the area between the Sabinal and Medina River basins which includes Seco and Hondo Creeks and an ungaged area between Hondo Creek and the Medina River basin (Basin 4); the Medina River basin (Basin 5); the area between the Medina River and the Cibolo Creek basin which is drained by the San Geronimo, Leon, and Salado Creeks, plus other smaller tributaries (Basin 6); the Cibolo Creek and Dry Comal Creek Basins (Basin 7); the Guadalupe River Basin (Basin 8); and the Blanco River Basin which also includes Sink, Purgatory, York, and Alligator Creeks (Basin 9) (Puente, 1978).
The basins included in the data release are titled Basin_1 through Basin_9. However, the data release does not include a contribution of recharge from Basin_8, the Guadalupe River basin. Estimated annual recharge to the Edwards aquifer from the Guadalupe River basin is considered negligible and therefore not calculated. The basins are defined and described in more detail in the report, Puente, 1978, Method of estimating natural recharge to the Edwards aquifer in the San Antonio area, Texas: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 78–10, 34 p.
overview.eadetcit: Slattery, R., and Choi, N., 2021, Estimated Annual Recharge to the Edwards Aquifer in the San Antonio Area, by Stream Basin or Ungaged Area, 1934–2020: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/P9QNWA5Y.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
